text: I'm going to talk about intersectionality
and entrepreneurship,

and the ways in which I
critique entrepreneurship
are as the master's tools,
because in many ways it's used
as an economic development policy
to foster inclusive economic development.

So, I'm going to be
looking at entrepreneurship
as that thing that I critique
through this lens of intersectionality,
because in many ways,
it's sort of touted as that tool
to help economic development be fostered
in an inclusive fashion,
when in reality, it is anything but.

So, I'm going to start with,
if you're familiar with me,
my research is generally fostered
around feminisms of the post-colonial
and transnational sort.
And today I arrive at it
from an intersectionality perspective.
I'm going to apply it to entrepreneurship.

And then I suppose at
the end, we'll do Q&A
when we're supposed to, sitting down.

For those of you familiar
with feminisms, great,
but there are many varieties
and streams associated with feminisms

and the ways in which I
sort of deploy them here

are arriving from an
intersectionality perspective.

So in that sense, I'm trying
to center the experiences
particularly of woman of color

in the book that I co-wrote
with Susan Clark Muntean

around the experiences of
women entrepreneurs in Boston
who are trying to succeed
but finding it extremely difficult.

So the talk today will focus
on some of those aspirations
and challenges that they're facing
despite the liberal claims in a city

that say they value and espouse
diversity and inclusion,
but the outcomes look quite different.

Some of the writing
that I do for this book
comes from academic frameworks
but what we discover in doing the research
is that the lived experiences of women
and those who identify as female,
often don't fit neatly into categories.

So in the book, we try to
dispel some of the myths
that all the experiences arriving

from a particular social
category are the same,

when in reality, there's
nuances, complexities,
and even, I would say counter examples

of how people are trying
to make it in a city
that is not built for them or by them.
The inspiration for the book comes from

many different years
of trying to understand

why diversity, equity
and inclusion efforts

generally don't work well in
the space of entrepreneurship

and entrepreneurial
ecosystems, in general.
And one of the inspirations for the book
comes from the work of Cynthia Enloe
and if you're familiar with her,

she has done some fantastic
work in political economy
from feminist perspectives,
asking us to take on an approach

that begs the question of
how do we make feminist sense
of the world around us.
And she gives a great example
of the Fukushima nuclear meltdown in Japan
and asks the question,
"How would a gender or a feminist analysis
rethink what happened?"
And many people would say,
"What are you talking about, Cynthia?
There's no women in the power plant."
And often that's the reasoning you get
when you ask someone about gender.

But in reality, what was
happening in the power plant

was there was a certain
form of toxic masculinity

that created a
hyper-competitive environment.
And a lot of people decided

that they were not going
to follow the rules.
So for me, a gender analysis,
a feminist making sense, allows for us

to see those interactions
that are gendered
and highly racialized in context,
where you may not think that they are.

Another inspiration comes
from the work of Tami Navarro,
where she asks about

how do we create knowledge
and create systems of change

so that the writing that we
do does not stay in the text
but has implications for change?
And that's really the inspiration
for the book that we co-wrote

is that hopefully it will
be an impetus for change
for people to change the narrative
around how they think about inclusion
within the space of entrepreneurship.
When we talk about intersectionality,
and I know many colleagues here
have defined it in their own terms,
I come at it from the ways in which

the intersecting dimensions
of gender and race
need to be understood in relationship

to the differential
experiences of women of color,

but in that sense, beyond
a new identity category.
A lot of times intersectionality
is used as a way to talk about identities.

In the book, we really tried
to understand it as beyond that
to address the structural, the political,
and the cultural elements

that often lead to the
particular experiences
of marginalization exclusion,
but also empowerment for women of color.

At the same time, there's some
critique of intersectionality
as in its limited ways in which
it still exemplifies neoliberal ideology

in terms of asking people
to see beyond differences.

And there's sort of these
four fundamental issues
with it that Nash identifies saying,

there's really a lack of
clearly defined methodology
that's associated with intersectionality.
The prototypical sort of person
that's centered is the black woman

when there are other
experiences and identities
that might need to be considered.

There's sort of this
ambiguity that's inherent
to the definition of intersectionality
and that there is sometimes an incoherence
between how we define categories
and the lived experiences of people.

I bring all that to
bear on entrepreneurship

to say that often when
we talk about diversity,
equity, and inclusion,

it's centered on certain
people and categories
when in fact people might not actually
fit into those categories so neatly.

One of the ways in which I
try to bring a DEI perspective
to entrepreneurship is to interrogate

what I call the historic
and contemporary ways
in which entrepreneurship unfolds

to make visible those
gendered and racialized ways

in which people engage in
their everyday activities.
The book that I am borrowing from today

is based on about a four
to five-year-old field--
a four to five-year-old longitudinal study
that focused on the experiences

of different entrepreneurs
in the Boston ecosystem.
And if you're familiar with Boston,

you know that it's an
incredibly fragmented city.
It is a city that has a historic landscape
of racial tensions.

And in many ways, it does
espouse a lot of liberal values.

So, you might think that the
ways in which the city acts
and supports entrepreneurs of color

or those from different
backgrounds might be really good,

but in fact, we find that
Boston, in many ways,

is actually much more
segregated than other cities
that might be known to you.

So what I want to do is
sort of break down the ways

in which intersectionality
helps us understand

why the approaches to be
inclusive in entrepreneurship
and to include people
who have been historically marginalized
are simply not going to work.

And in that way, what I want
to do is sort of share with you

the ways in which
intersectionality allows us
to see what's happening in ways
that are different that sort of challenge

the diversity, equity,
and inclusion initiatives

that tend to fall on either
individuals or organizations

when really the problems
are quite systemic.
So in that way,

intersectionality as a
framework allows us to see
and consider how power is a relevant part
of the institutional arrangements
and the creation of an environment
that tends to favor and reward,

even if unintentionally,
certain genders, races,
and immigrant backgrounds over others.

And it tends to exacerbate
existing inequalities
across social categories.
So, what I often find is that

when we talk about diversity,
equity, and inclusion,
we don't tend to talk about power as much.

And so one of my approaches
to talking about DEI
within the context of entrepreneurship

is to say that power is an
important and missing dimension

from any analysis that
touts entrepreneurship

as a way to create inclusive
economic development.

One of the things that we
see in entrepreneurship
is that the role and importance

of networks and social
capital is paramount

to how people are able
to navigate the resources

of an entrepreneurial ecosystem
in a city, in general.

And by using trusted
networks and social relations
as a proxy to reduce transaction costs
which is how venture capitalists operate,
what they're essentially doing is trying
to find a way to do due diligence

and to give money to
people that they trust.
And in the research,

what we find is despite
espousing diversity,

equity, and inclusion as
important belief systems,

who they end up funding and
who they end up investing in

are actually quite the
opposite of the people
that they claim to value.

So, what we find is that
when people say "trust,"

what they really want to
say is "around whiteness,"
in the Boston ecosystem.
And the other sort of expectation

is that reducing transaction
costs seems to be
the only measure of economic success
that is deemed as an appropriate approach
for economic development, when in reality,

we know that when you
approach the social networks
in a way that creates inequalities,
it simply furthers existing inequalities

rather than create new
opportunities for individuals.
So if we assume that everyone
in an entrepreneurial ecosystem
has the exact same opportunities,

then we can say that the
ways in which funding
is taking place is merit-based.

When in reality what
we actually see is that
it's anything but meritocratic.

In fact, one of the ways
we use to describe it

is based on the work of
Eduardo Bonilla-Silva
in terms of colorblind racism,

and its sort of proxy
of gender blind sexism,
in that the prevailing ways in which

entrepreneurship gets done
are racialized and gendered
in ways that make them invisible
to those who are practicing these works.
So at the end, what we find is that
because the phenomenon we're studying,
entrepreneurial ecosystems,
are neither hierarchies or organizations,
but act like trusted networks,

which is how people
get access to resources
through social capital,

we find that depending
on where you're located
in terms of your social category,

you may or may not have
access to certain information.
And depending on that,

you may or may not have
access to the information
and opportunities that are embedded
in the ecosystem in itself.
One of the other sort of findings
that we have in this research is that
there seem to be little to none
sanctions for violations
for breaking the norms of an ecosystem.

And we draw on the work
that has demonstrated

that there are gendered
outcomes to behaviors
that are stereotypically male.
So, we sort of give the example
of Ellen Pao v. Kleiner Perkins
where she sued them for sexual harassment,

and the attorneys on
the Kleiner Perkins side
argued that she was vengeful, vindictive,
and she actually lost her lawsuit.
On the flip side,

we sort of talk about those
masculinized behaviors
by Travis Kalanick at Uber

who created an opportunity
for sexual harassment
to take shape.
And he was able to exit the company
with about $2.2 billion in severance check

and continues to circulate
in a very successful way
in ecosystems.

We bring all these conversations
to bear on the fact that
entrepreneurship is touted as a tool

for economic development
globally not just here in the US.
And when we see that the ways
in which entrepreneurship takes place,
despite claims of inclusion,

actually replicate
neoliberal inequalities,

I think we have something to
say in terms of policymakers.
So, one of the things that we do do
in terms of the book that we have

is we look at the ways
in which gender, race,
and immigrant status impact the ways

in which power, social
capital, and social structures
influence the individual experiences

and the organizational actions
of these different actors.
So, as an example, when we speak to women

who are entrepreneurs and who
self-identify as of color,
they'll often say that they will speak
to many, many white male investors
who are very interested in supporting them
and understanding what their venture is.
But when they ask for money,
they will say, "Let me introduce you
to this Black investor."
So, there's often this sort of siloing

and moving of individuals
across ecosystems
to the appropriate sources of investments,
so there's a siloing by gender and race.
At the same time,

we see that a lot of organizations
are trying to do better.
Although we don't name them in the book,
you can probably guess who they are.

There are some brand name
accelerators and incubators
in the Boston ecosystem and nationally
that are very much interested

in creating inclusive
opportunities for entrepreneurship.
And in speaking to them,

what they will mention is they
get thousands of applicants
and they have a cohort of 10.
And what they do is to take two or three
from the actual pool of applicants
and the seven to eight or even nine
will come from referrals

of those who are in
their trusted networks.

So if you're an entrepreneur
who doesn't have that network,

you literally have very little
to no chance of getting in.

But if you go to the
websites of these firms,
you often see that they're touting
the diversity of their cohorts
and the ways in which inclusion
is an important part of who they are
as an identity, as a brand.

So, one of the ways to identify
these sort of dichotomies

of the espoused values
versus the enacted ones
is in engaging in conversations,
we often find that every single founder
that we spoke to and investor we spoke to

said they value diversity
if they were white and male

but when you looked at
their hiring practices

or you asked them about
succession planning

or you asked them about their
organizational practices,

it came back to, we want
to hire the best person.
We want to grow,

and then we'll think about
diversity, equity, and inclusion.

So what we find is that in
the space of entrepreneurship,
there really are not a lot of efforts
to change the outcomes,
even though there's a lot of conversation

around how to espouse diversity,
equity, and inclusion.
I also wanted to point out that
there's also a growing trend
of trying to get women investors

to invest in more women
or women-led startups,
which is another way in which

diversity, equity, and
inclusion is getting done.

Unfortunately, there's research
that demonstrates from 2020,
that firms with female founders
who receive funding from female
rather than male venture capitalists

are two times less likely
to raise additional funding,
because there's a stigma associated
with getting money from women. (laughs)
And sadly the research shows
that there's actually no equivalent
for male-backed firms, right?
So, women can invest in women,

and then they stigmatize
the women-led company,

but women investors who
invest in male companies,
the males actually are not stigmatized.
So, what this tells us
is that diversity equity initiatives
that try to create funding folds for women
or women led-companies may actually end up
not only stigmatizing the women companies
but also the investors themselves
in suggesting that there might be bias
in who they're investing in.
So at the end of the day,

we really have to question
whether or not initiatives

that focus on gender or
race are ending up hurting
versus supporting entrepreneurs

who want to be able to
engage in entrepreneurship.

Lastly, one of the things
that I want to address
is that the ways in which we talk about
diversity, equity and inclusion matter.
Often in entrepreneurship,
we'll talk about the lack of access
to finance or information.

If we continue talking
about lack of access,

what we're saying is we
want you to still stay
within the structures that are built
versus saying maybe the conversation

should be on control and
decision making over capital,
which would fundamentally require us

to rethink the structures
of entrepreneurship
rather than to create access for people
who've been marginalized.

So for me, in the context
of entrepreneurship,

DEI is not only about sort
of changing the practices
but the language around how we think about

the ways in which the
structures we're embedded in
creates certain opportunities
for some people and not others.
So at the end of the day,

intersectionality allows us
to see and do certain things
which is how the interactions
and the outcomes and experiences

speak to the complexity of
race, gender, immigrant status,
and any other sort of category
within the context of entrepreneurship,
moreso than any individual category
could itself get us to understand.

And that the entrepreneurial
behavior norms
within ecosystems are explicitly
and implicitly gendered and racialized.
And the ways in which you surface these,

I would say gendered and
racialized assumptions,

is by asking direct
questions that kind of,
I would say, expose these assumptions
that leaders and investors have.
And at the end of the day,

it's a matter of you can
espouse all the values you want,
but if you have these assumptions
and you're acting on them,

fundamentally, we're not really
going to change anything.

And lastly, the idea
that startup communities,
it's a huge craze in the US right now,
of startup ecosystems, startup craze,

and moving to certain
cities to fund ventures.

We have to understand that
communities include people
but they also exclude people.

So understanding that within
the context of entrepreneurship
is really interesting.

Lastly, we have to
understand for policymakers

that when you decide that you're
going to build an ecosystem
to support entrepreneurship,

having DEI policies by
themselves are not enough.
You have to understand the ways in which
the ecosystem as a whole is behaving

in terms of the people
who are getting funding
and those who are not.
Differences matter, absolutely.

But at the same time
you have to understand
that when we talk about inclusion,

we have to talk about its
shadow, which is inequality,

which is what the driver of
entrepreneurship has been
for a long time in the US.
I'll leave you with this.
If you're interested in all these,
this is the book that I used today

to talk about the
research that my colleague

Susan and I completed
in the Boston ecosystem.
It's, I would say, a just example of
the kind of inclusive and exclusive ways
in which cities behave and ultimately,

whether or not diversity,
equity, and inclusion

is sufficient to move us
away from the inequalities
we see on the rise in the US today.
(audience clapping)
